Explanation: EV indicates that the drug, service, or procedure requires review through Evicore before coverage is approved.
Drugs managed or reviewed under the PICA Program for utilization management and clinical review.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.
Specialty drugs are used to treat difficult, long-term conditions. You may need to get this drug through a specialty pharmacy.
Generic or brand drugs that are available at the lowest cost share for the plan
Generic or brand drugs that the plan offers at a higher cost to you than Tier 1 Preferred Generic drugs
This tier includes preferred brand-name drugs as well as some generic drugs.

Explanation: Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.

PAYER NAME: AARP Medicare Plans from United Healthcare
Explanation: Additional quantity limits may apply to all opioid drugs used to treat pain. This additional limit is called a cumulative morphine milligram equivalent (MME). It’s designed to monitor safe dosing levels of opioids for people who may be taking more than 1 opioid drug for pain management. If your doctor or prescriber prescribes more than this amount or thinks the limit is not right for your situation, you or your doctor or prescriber can ask the plan to cover the additional quantity.

PAYER NAME: AARP Medicare Plans from United Healthcare
Explanation:

of using opioids. This limit helps minimize long-term opioid use.

Explanation: For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

PAYER NAME: AARP Medicare Plans from United Healthcare
Explanation: In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

PAYER NAME: AARP Medicare Plans from United Healthcare
EXPANSION: Medicare Part B or Part D
Explanation:
Depending on how this drug is used, it may be covered by either Medicare Part B (doctor and
outpatient health care) or Medicare Part D (prescription drugs).

PAYER NAME: AARP Medicare Plans from United Healthcare
Explanation: Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.

PAYER NAME: AARP Medicare Plans from United Healthcare
Explanation: Additional quantity limits may apply to all opioid drugs used to treat pain. This additional limit is called a cumulative morphine milligram equivalent (MME). It’s designed to monitor safe dosing levels of opioids for people who may be taking more than 1 opioid drug for pain management. If your doctor or prescriber prescribes more than this amount or thinks the limit is not right for your situation, you or your doctor or prescriber can ask the plan to cover the additional quantity.

PAYER NAME: AARP Medicare Plans from United Healthcare
Explanation:
An opioid drug used to treat pain may be limited to a 7-day supply if you don’t have a recent history
of using opioids. This limit helps minimize long-term opioid use.

Explanation: Dispensing limits apply to this drug. This drug is limited to a 1-month supply per prescription.

Depending on how this drug is used, it may be covered by either Medicare Part B (doctor and
outpatient health care) or Medicare Part D (prescription drugs).

PAYER NAME: AARP Medicare Plans from United Healthcare
Explanation: Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.

PAYER NAME: AARP Medicare Plans from United Healthcare
Explanation: Additional quantity limits may apply to all opioid drugs used to treat pain. This additional limit is called a cumulative morphine milligram equivalent (MME). It’s designed to monitor safe dosing levels of opioids for people who may be taking more than 1 opioid drug for pain management. If your doctor or prescriber prescribes more than this amount or thinks the limit is not right for your situation, you or your doctor or prescriber can ask the plan to cover the additional quantity.

PAYER NAME: AARP Medicare Plans from United Healthcare
Explanation:
An opioid drug used to treat pain may be limited to a 7-day supply if you don’t have a recent history
of using opioids. This limit helps minimize long-term opioid use.

PAYER NAME: AARP Medicare Plans from United Healthcare
Explanation: Dispensing limits apply to this drug. This drug is limited to a 1-month supply per prescription.

Explanation: Generic or brand drugs that are available at the lowest cost share for the plan

Explanation: This tier includes preferred brand-name drugs as well as some generic drugs.

Explanation: Some injectables and other high-cost drugs

PAYER NAME: AARP Medicare Plans from United Healthcare
Explanation: Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

PAYER NAME: AARP Medicare Plans from United Healthcare
Explanation: For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

PAYER NAME: AARP Medicare Plans from United Healthcare
Explanation: In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

Explanation: Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

PAYER NAME: AARP Medicare Plans from United Healthcare
Explanation: For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

PAYER NAME: AARP Medicare Plans from United Healthcare
Explanation: In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

PAYER NAME: AARP Medicare Plans from United Healthcare
EXPANSION: Medicare Part B or Part D
Explanation:
Depending on how this drug is used, it may be covered by either Medicare Part B (doctor and
outpatient health care) or Medicare Part D (prescription drugs).

PAYER NAME: AARP Medicare Plans from United Healthcare
Explanation: Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.

PAYER NAME: AARP Medicare Plans from United Healthcare
Explanation: Additional quantity limits may apply to all opioid drugs used to treat pain. This additional limit is called a cumulative morphine milligram equivalent (MME). It’s designed to monitor safe dosing levels of opioids for people who may be taking more than 1 opioid drug for pain management. If your doctor or prescriber prescribes more than this amount or thinks the limit is not right for your situation, you or your doctor or prescriber can ask the plan to cover the additional quantity.

PAYER NAME: AARP Medicare Plans from United Healthcare
Explanation:
An opioid drug used to treat pain may be limited to a 7-day supply if you don’t have a recent history
of using opioids. This limit helps minimize long-term opioid use.

Quantity level limits help encourage medication use as intended by the FDA. Quantity level limits are placed on medications in certain drug categories. For the medications listed in this document, if a quantity level limit applies, it will generally be noted next to the medication with a dot under the quantity level limits column. Limits may include quantity of covered medication per prescription, quantity of covered medication in a given time period, coverage only for members within a certain age range, and coverage only for members of a specific gender. If your doctor prescribes a greater quantity of medication than what the quantity level limit allows, you can still get the medication

Additional quantity limits may apply to all opioid drugs used to treat pain. This additional limit is called a cumulative morphine milligram equivalent (MME). It’s designed to monitor safe dosing levels of opioids for people who may be taking more than 1 opioid drug for pain management. If your doctor or prescriber prescribes more than this amount or thinks the limit is not right for your situation, you or your doctor or prescriber can ask the plan to cover the additional quantity.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.
An OTC drug is a non-prescription drug.

Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.

Without prior approval, we may not cover this drug.

A generic medication is called by its chemical name; a manufacturer 
assigns a brand name. Both generic and brand name products have the same active ingredients. Overall, the 
generic medication is just as safe and effective as the brand name medication.  Preferred generic drugs are 
generally the most cost-effective. Includes most generic drugs.
These drugs may cost more than generics but less than non-preferred brands.

Non-preferred brand medications may have generic equivalents. Once a branded medication becomes available as a generic product, it moves to a non-preferred brand tier, and the generic becomes a non-preferred generic medication unless otherwise noted in the formulary. Non-preferred brand drugs are generally higher in cost than preferred brands.

Specialty medications are typically high-cost, self-administered (oral or injectable) drugs requiring significant support to manage and administer. These drugs often treat rare, chronic conditions and may require unique delivery or dispensing considerations. They usually involve additional patient support, safety monitoring, and compliance assistance.

Some medicines have special requirements where your doctor must provide clinical information to Prime Therapeutics before the medicine will be approved and covered. This ensures medicines are prescribed appropriately and only when medically necessary.

Additional quantity limits may apply to all opioid drugs used to treat pain. This additional limit is called a cumulative morphine milligram equivalent (MME). It’s designed to monitor safe dosing levels of opioids for people who may be taking more than 1 opioid drug for pain management. If your doctor or prescriber prescribes more than this amount or thinks the limit is not right for your situation, you or your doctor or prescriber can ask the plan to cover the additional quantity.

AGE (Age Requirement) refers to the minimum or maximum age limits set by insurance policies or healthcare plans that determine eligibility for coverage or specific benefits, ensuring treatment or coverage is appropriate for the patient’s age group.
Brand-name drugs on an insurance formulary that are favored due to negotiated discounts or rebates, resulting in lower copayments or coinsurance compared to non-preferred brand drugs.

Oscar offers several condition specific plans (as 
described above) and these medications might be 
lower cost for members enrolled in one of these 
plans

These reviews are built into the pharmacy claim adjudication system to review a member’s prescription history 
for possible drug related problems including drug-drug interactions and drug therapy duplications. Drugs 
may reject at the Point-of-Sale (POS) and/or generate a message to the dispensing pharmacist when there is a 
safety concern. The dispensing pharmacist can review the issue with the provider and override the rejection if 
appropriate for most edits.

EXPANSION: Medicare Part B or Part D
Explanation:
Depending on how this drug is used, it may be covered by either Medicare Part B (doctor and
outpatient health care) or Medicare Part D (prescription drugs).

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

Additional quantity limits may apply to all opioid drugs used to treat pain. This additional limit is called a cumulative morphine milligram equivalent (MME). It’s designed to monitor safe dosing levels of opioids for people who may be taking more than 1 opioid drug for pain management. If your doctor or prescriber prescribes more than this amount or thinks the limit is not right for your situation, you or your doctor or prescriber can ask the plan to cover the additional quantity.
This prescription drug is not available through mail order service.

BvsD (Part B vs Part D) refers to the distinction between Medicare Part B and Part D drug coverage: Part B covers certain medications typically administered in medical settings (like injections, infusions, or durable medical equipment) such as immunosuppressants and some cancer drugs, while Part D covers most outpatient prescription drugs taken at home, including chronic condition medications.
This prescription cannot be filled for more than a 30-day supply.

Specialty drugs or high-cost non-preferred brands

“Generic drug” is the same drug as its BRAND name equivalent in dosage, safety, strength, how it is taken, quality, 
performance, and intended use. A generic drug is listed in bold and italicized lowercase letters.
Specialty drugs are used to treat difficult, long-term conditions. You may need to get this drug through a specialty pharmacy.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

BvsD (Part B vs Part D) refers to the distinction between Medicare Part B and Part D drug coverage: Part B covers certain medications typically administered in medical settings (like injections, infusions, or durable medical equipment) such as immunosuppressants and some cancer drugs, while Part D covers most outpatient prescription drugs taken at home, including chronic condition medications.
This prescription cannot be filled for more than a 30-day supply.

For certain kinds of drugs, you can use CVS Caremark® Mail Service Pharmacy. Generally, the drugs available through mail order are drugs that you take on a regular basis, for a chronic or long‑term medical condition. The drugs available through our plan’s mail‑order service are marked as “MO” in our Drug List. *

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

AGE (Age Requirement) refers to the minimum or maximum age limits set by insurance policies or healthcare plans that determine eligibility for coverage or specific benefits, ensuring treatment or coverage is appropriate for the patient’s age group.

A medical benefit drug is a drug that is not generally self-administered and 
administered by a health care professional. The outpatient prescription drug benefit 
includes FDA approved drugs that are self-administered, commonly oral, or self
injectable drugs, not otherwise excluded from coverage.
An OTC drug is a non-prescription drug.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

SGM is our utilization management program that helps ensure appropriate utilization for 
specialty medication based on currently accepted evidence-based medicine guidelines. 
SGM is designed to help ensure safety and efficacy while preventing off-guideline 
utilization. Specialty medications are identified in the document as SGM.

BvsD (Part B vs Part D) refers to the distinction between Medicare Part B and Part D drug coverage: Part B covers certain medications typically administered in medical settings (like injections, infusions, or durable medical equipment) such as immunosuppressants and some cancer drugs, while Part D covers most outpatient prescription drugs taken at home, including chronic condition medications.

Quantity level limits help encourage medication use as intended by the FDA. Quantity level limits are placed on medications in certain drug categories. For the medications listed in this document, if a quantity level limit applies, it will generally be noted next to the medication with a dot under the quantity level limits column. Limits may include quantity of covered medication per prescription, quantity of covered medication in a given time period, coverage only for members within a certain age range, and coverage only for members of a specific gender. If your doctor prescribes a greater quantity of medication than what the quantity level limit allows, you can still get the medication

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

Quantity level limits help encourage medication use as intended by the FDA. Quantity level limits are placed on medications in certain drug categories. For the medications listed in this document, if a quantity level limit applies, it will generally be noted next to the medication with a dot under the quantity level limits column. Limits may include quantity of covered medication per prescription, quantity of covered medication in a given time period, coverage only for members within a certain age range, and coverage only for members of a specific gender. If your doctor prescribes a greater quantity of medication than what the quantity level limit allows, you can still get the medication

EXPANSION: Prior Authorization Restriction for Part B vs Part D Determination
Explanation: This drug may be eligible for payment under Medicare Part B, or Part D. You (or your provider) may be required to get authorization from us to determine that this drug is covered under Medicare Part D before you fill your prescription for this drug. Without prior approval, we may not cover this drug.

EXPANSION: Prior Authorization Restriction for New Starts Only
Explanation: Prior authorization applies only for new users or members; it does not apply for those already receiving the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. EXPANSION: Prior Authorization Restriction for Part B vs Part D Determination
Explanation: This drug may be eligible for payment under Medicare Part B, or Part D. You (or your provider) may be required to get authorization from us to determine that this drug is covered under Medicare Part D before you fill your prescription for this drug. Without prior approval, we may not cover this drug.

EXPANSION: Prior Authorization Restriction for New Starts Only
Explanation: Prior authorization applies only for new users or members; it does not apply for those already receiving the drug.

EXPANSION:
Prior Authorization 
Restriction for High 
Risk Medications
Explanation:
High Risk medications that require a prior 
authorization.

EXPANSION: Prior Authorization (New Starts Only – High Risk Meds)
Explanation:
If you are a new member, you (or your 
physician) are required to get a prior authorization before you fill your prescription for this drug. This drug has been deemed by CMS to be potentially harmful and therefore a High-Risk Medication for Medicare beneficiaries 65 years or older. Without prior authorization, this drug may not be covered

BvsD (Part B vs Part D) refers to the distinction between Medicare Part B and Part D drug coverage: Part B covers certain medications typically administered in medical settings (like injections, infusions, or durable medical equipment) such as immunosuppressants and some cancer drugs, while Part D covers most outpatient prescription drugs taken at home, including chronic condition medications.

This is a specialty medication, which is used to treat rare and/or complex medical conditions. They’re typically injected or infused and may need special handling, such as refrigeration.

Limited Distribution Drug (LDD) refers to a medication that is dispensed through a restricted network of pharmacies, often because it is used to treat complex, rare, or specialty medical conditions. These drugs are usually managed by the pharmaceutical manufacturers who limit distribution to specific, highly trained pharmacies to ensure proper handling, storage, administration, and monitoring.

Limited Distribution Drug (LDD) refers to a medication that is dispensed through a restricted network of pharmacies, often because it is used to treat complex, rare, or specialty medical conditions. Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

BvsD (Part B vs Part D) refers to the distinction between Medicare Part B and Part D drug coverage: Part B covers certain medications typically administered in medical settings (like injections, infusions, or durable medical equipment) such as immunosuppressants and some cancer drugs, while Part D covers most outpatient prescription drugs taken at home, including chronic condition medications.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.
Coverage may be dependent on the specialty of the prescribing physician
Specialty drugs are used to treat difficult, long-term conditions. You may need to get this drug through a specialty pharmacy.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

EXPANSION: Prior Authorization Restriction for New Starts Only
Explanation: Prior authorization applies only for new users or members; it does not apply for those already receiving the drug.

EXPANSION: Prior Authorization Restriction for Part B vs Part D Determination
Explanation: This drug may be eligible for payment under Medicare Part B, or Part D. Without prior approval, we may not cover this drug.

Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.

AGE (Age Requirement) refers to the minimum or maximum age limits set by insurance policies or healthcare plans that determine eligibility for coverage or specific benefits, ensuring treatment or coverage is appropriate for the patient’s age group.

BvsD (Part B vs Part D) refers to the distinction between Medicare Part B and Part D drug coverage: Part B covers certain medications typically administered in medical settings (like injections, infusions, or durable medical equipment) such as immunosuppressants and some cancer drugs, while Part D covers most outpatient prescription drugs taken at home, including chronic condition medications.

Under this health care reform law, if you qualify, you can get your drug at no cost if it is right for your age and condition and used properly.

AGE (Age Requirement) refers to the minimum or maximum age limits set by insurance policies or healthcare plans that determine eligibility for coverage or specific benefits, ensuring treatment or coverage is appropriate for the patient’s age group.

Eligible Charge means the maximum amount your insurance plan will pay for a covered medical service or prescription drug. It is also called the “allowed amount,” “eligible expense,” “payment allowance,” or “negotiated rate

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.
Specialty drugs are used to treat difficult, long-term conditions. You may need to get this drug through a specialty pharmacy.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

Specialty medications are typically high-cost, self-administered (oral or injectable) drugs requiring significant support to manage and administer. These drugs often treat rare, chronic conditions and may require unique delivery or dispensing considerations. They usually involve additional patient support, safety monitoring, and compliance assistance.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

Explanation:
Depending on how this drug is used, it may be covered by either Medicare Part B (doctor and
outpatient health care) or Medicare Part D (prescription drugs).
Dispensing limits apply to this drug. This drug is limited to a 1-month supply per prescription.

For certain kinds of drugs, you can use CVS Caremark® Mail Service Pharmacy. Generally, the drugs available through mail order are drugs that you take on a regular basis, for a chronic or long‑term medical condition. The drugs available through our plan’s mail‑order service are marked as “MO” in our Drug List. *

Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.

Depending on how this drug is used, it may be covered by either Medicare Part B (doctor and
outpatient health care) or Medicare Part D (prescription drugs).
Dispensing limits apply to this drug. This drug is limited to a 1-month supply per prescription.

For certain kinds of drugs, you can use CVS Caremark® Mail Service Pharmacy. Generally, the drugs available through mail order are drugs that you take on a regular basis, for a chronic or long‑term medical condition. The drugs available through our plan’s mail‑order service are marked as “MO” in our Drug List. *

Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

Limited Distribution Drug (LDD) refers to a medication that is dispensed through a restricted network of pharmacies, often because it is used to treat complex, rare, or specialty medical conditions. These drugs are usually managed by the pharmaceutical manufacturers who limit distribution to specific, highly trained pharmacies to ensure proper handling, storage, administration, and monitoring.

of certain medications to be filled. Medications 
eligible to be filled for a 90-day maintenance 
supply are indicated on the formulary with an 
“MM.”

These medications are covered at $0 under preventive benefit
Specialty drugs are used to treat difficult, long-term conditions. You may need to get this drug through a specialty pharmacy.

Part B medications are outpatient prescription drugs covered by Medicare Part B. Typically, these are drugs administered by a health care professional in settings like a doctor's office, outpatient clinic, or hospital.
You may need to use another recommended drug first before a prescribed drug is covered.

Medications, vitamins and/or supplements. Medications that have a rating of “A” or “B” in the current recommendations of the United States Preventive Services Task Force and only when prescribed by a health care Practitioner and/or Provider are available at a $0 copay (no member cost-share) if the member meets specific conditions, such as age or gender. If the member does not meet the specific conditions, the usual member benefit will apply

These are medications included on the plan's Preferred Drug List (PDL) or formulary because they offer the best therapeutic value for the lowest net cost, based on clinical evidence and negotiations with pharmaceutical manufacturers.

Refers to specialty drugs that are high-cost, complex medications placed in a non-preferred tier on insurance formularies, leading to higher patient cost-sharing and often requiring special handling and prior authorization.
Indicates that coverage for the medication requires an additional rider or amendment to the standard plan. The drug may only be covered if the rider is active and applicable to the member’s plan.
medications that are not advised for routine use within the formulary

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

Insurance coverage for a drug or treatment is determined based on the specific medical condition or indication for which the drug is prescribed, often requiring that the drug be used only for FDA-approved or medically supported indications to qualify for coverage.
An OTC drug is a non-prescription drug.

The drugs available through our plan’s mail‑order service are marked as “MO” in our Drug List. *

Medication Assisted Treatment (MAT) combines FDA-approved medications with counseling and behavioral therapies to treat substance use disorders effectively.
These are drugs that are limited to a 30-day supply on your plan.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.
Specialty drugs are used to treat difficult, long-term conditions. You may need to get this drug through a specialty pharmacy.

Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.

For certain kinds of drugs, you can use CVS Caremark® Mail Service Pharmacy. Generally, the drugs available through mail order are drugs that you take on a regular basis, for a chronic or long‑term medical condition. The drugs available through our plan’s mail‑order service are marked as “MO” in our Drug List. *

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

Additional quantity limits may apply to all opioid drugs used to treat pain. This additional limit is called a cumulative morphine milligram equivalent (MME). It’s designed to monitor safe dosing levels of opioids for people who may be taking more than 1 opioid drug for pain management. If your doctor or prescriber prescribes more than this amount or thinks the limit is not right for your situation, you or your doctor or prescriber can ask the plan to cover the additional quantity.

An opioid drug used to treat pain may be limited to a 7-day supply if you don’t have a recent history
of using opioids. This limit helps minimize long-term opioid use.
Dispensing limits apply to this drug. This drug is limited to a 1-month supply per prescription.

EXPANSION: Medicare Part B or Part D
Explanation:
Depending on how this drug is used, it may be covered by either Medicare Part B (doctor and
outpatient health care) or Medicare Part D (prescription drugs).

Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.

Additional quantity limits may apply to all opioid drugs used to treat pain. This additional limit is called a cumulative morphine milligram equivalent (MME). It’s designed to monitor safe dosing levels of opioids for people who may be taking more than 1 opioid drug for pain management. If your doctor or prescriber prescribes more than this amount or thinks the limit is not right for your situation, you or your doctor or prescriber can ask the plan to cover the additional quantity.

An opioid drug used to treat pain may be limited to a 7-day supply if you don’t have a recent history
of using opioids. This limit helps minimize long-term opioid use.
Dispensing limits apply to this drug. This drug is limited to a 1-month supply per prescription.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

EXPANSION: Medicare Part B or Part D
Explanation:
Depending on how this drug is used, it may be covered by either Medicare Part B (doctor and
outpatient health care) or Medicare Part D (prescription drugs).

Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.

Additional quantity limits may apply to all opioid drugs used to treat pain. This additional limit is called a cumulative morphine milligram equivalent (MME). It’s designed to monitor safe dosing levels of opioids for people who may be taking more than 1 opioid drug for pain management. If your doctor or prescriber prescribes more than this amount or thinks the limit is not right for your situation, you or your doctor or prescriber can ask the plan to cover the additional quantity.

An opioid drug used to treat pain may be limited to a 7-day supply if you don’t have a recent history
of using opioids. This limit helps minimize long-term opioid use.
Dispensing limits apply to this drug. This drug is limited to a 1-month supply per prescription.
Generic or brand drugs that are available at the lowest cost share for the plan
Generic or brand drugs that the plan offers at a higher cost to you than Tier 1 Preferred Generic drugs
This tier includes preferred brand-name drugs as well as some generic drugs.
Specialty drugs or high-cost non-preferred brands
Some injectables and other high-cost drugs

Medicine that may be unsafe in patients greater than 65 years of age. Our formulary does include coverage for some of these drugs, but alternatives may be found in lower co-pay tiers.
An OTC drug is a non-prescription drug.
A drug formulation designed to release the active ingredient after a specific delay, usually past the stomach. It helps protect the drug from stomach acid and ensures targeted or timed delivery.

Eligible Charge means the maximum amount your insurance plan will pay for a covered medical service or prescription drug. It is also called the “allowed amount,” “eligible expense,” “payment allowance,” or “negotiated rate
Extended-release (also known as sustained-release), refer to the reference brand listed for clarification
Specialty drugs are used to treat difficult, long-term conditions. You may need to get this drug through a specialty pharmacy.
Refers to the identification of a medical condition or disease. Coverage varies by diagnosis, meaning insurance benefits depend on the specific condition being treated.
This prescription drug may only be covered for a single gender.
Minimum and maximum age requirements set by an insurance policy or plan that determine when an individual can apply for coverage or renew a policy, often used to manage risk and eligibility.

Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.

Additional quantity limits may apply to all opioid drugs used to treat pain. This additional limit is called a cumulative morphine milligram equivalent (MME). It’s designed to monitor safe dosing levels of opioids for people who may be taking more than 1 opioid drug for pain management. If your doctor or prescriber prescribes more than this amount or thinks the limit is not right for your situation, you or your doctor or prescriber can ask the plan to cover the additional quantity.

An opioid drug used to treat pain may be limited to a 7-day supply if you don’t have a recent history
of using opioids. This limit helps minimize long-term opioid use.
Dispensing limits apply to this drug. This drug is limited to a 1-month supply per prescription.

Part B medications are outpatient prescription drugs covered by Medicare Part B. Typically, these are drugs administered by a health care professional in settings like a doctor's office, outpatient clinic, or hospital.
You may need to use another recommended drug first before a prescribed drug is covered.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

EXPANSION: Prior Authorization Restriction for Part B vs Part D Determination
Explanation: This drug may be eligible for payment under Medicare Part B, or Part D. You (or your provider) may be required to get authorization from us to determine that this drug is covered under Medicare Part D before you fill your prescription for this drug. Without prior approval, we may not cover this drug.

EXPANSION: Prior Authorization Restriction for New Starts Only
Explanation: Prior authorization applies only for new users or members; it does not apply for those already receiving the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.
This prescription drug is not available through mail order service.
This drug is only available for a one-month supply.

Explanation:
Depending on how this drug is used, it may be covered by either Medicare Part B (doctor and
outpatient health care) or Medicare Part D (prescription drugs).

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

This prescription drug is not normally covered in a Medicare Prescription Drug Plan. The amount you pay when you fill a prescription for this drug does not count towards your total drug costs (that is, the amount you pay does not help you qualify for catastrophic coverage).

Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.
Generic or brand drugs that are available at the lowest cost share for the plan
Generic or brand drugs that the plan offers at a higher cost to you than Tier 1 Preferred Generic drugs
This tier includes preferred brand-name drugs as well as some generic drugs.
Specialty drugs or high-cost non-preferred brands
Some injectables and other high-cost drugs
Zero-dollar ($0) cost tier. This tier includes limited drug categories (i.e., certain high blood pressure, high cholesterol, vaccines, and oral diabetic drugs).

No copayment for those drugs that are used for prevention and are mandated by the Affordable Care Act. Select oral contraceptives, vitamin D, folic acid for women of child bearing age, over-the-counter (OTC) aspirin, and smoking cessation products may be covered under this tier. Certain age limits may apply.

EXPANSION: Medicare Part B or Part D
Explanation:
Depending on how this drug is used, it may be covered by either Medicare Part B (doctor and
outpatient health care) or Medicare Part D (prescription drugs).

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

Quantity level limits help encourage medication use as intended by the FDA. Quantity level limits are placed on medications in certain drug categories. For the medications listed in this document, if a quantity level limit applies, it will generally be noted next to the medication with a dot under the quantity level limits column. Limits may include quantity of covered medication per prescription, quantity of covered medication in a given time period, coverage only for members within a certain age range, and coverage only for members of a specific gender. If your doctor prescribes a greater quantity of medication than what the quantity level limit allows, you can still get the medication
Indicates that the amount of medication covered is limited for the entire course of therapy. Prescriptions exceeding this limit require prior authorization or an exception for coverage.

BvsD (Part B vs Part D) refers to the distinction between Medicare Part B and Part D drug coverage: Part B covers certain medications typically administered in medical settings (like injections, infusions, or durable medical equipment) such as immunosuppressants and some cancer drugs, while Part D covers most outpatient prescription drugs taken at home, including chronic condition medications.

The Plan requires you or your physician to get prior authorization for certain drugs. 
This means that you will need to get approval from The Plan before you fill your prescriptions. If you

In some cases, The Plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical 
condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both 
treat your medical condition, The Plan may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does 
not work for you, The Plan will then cover Drug B.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

prescription for this drug. Without prior approval, The Plan may not cover this drug.

not work for you, The Plan will then cover Drug B.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

For certain kinds of drugs, you can use CVS Caremark® Mail Service Pharmacy. Generally, the drugs available through mail order are drugs that you take on a regular basis, for a chronic or long‑term medical condition. The drugs available through our plan’s mail‑order service are marked as “MO” in our Drug List. *
These drugs are available only through certain pharmacies or wholesalers, depending on what the manufacturer decides.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

For certain kinds of drugs, you can use CVS Caremark® Mail Service Pharmacy. Generally, the drugs available through mail order are drugs that you take on a regular basis, for a chronic or long‑term medical condition. The drugs available through our plan’s mail‑order service are marked as “MO” in our Drug List. *
These drugs are available only through certain pharmacies or wholesalers, depending on what the manufacturer decides.

These drugs are for complex medical conditions and may require special handling and/or close monitoring. They are available through CVS Specialty Pharmacy Services and may be available at other specialty pharmacies in the network

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

For certain kinds of drugs, you can use CVS Caremark® Mail Service Pharmacy. Generally, the drugs available through mail order are drugs that you take on a regular basis, for a chronic or long‑term medical condition. The drugs available through our plan’s mail‑order service are marked as “MO” in our Drug List. *
These drugs are available only through certain pharmacies or wholesalers, depending on what the manufacturer decides.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

For certain kinds of drugs, you can use CVS Caremark® Mail Service Pharmacy. Generally, the drugs available through mail order are drugs that you take on a regular basis, for a chronic or long‑term medical condition. The drugs available through our plan’s mail‑order service are marked as “MO” in our Drug List. *
These drugs are available only through certain pharmacies or wholesalers, depending on what the manufacturer decides.

Refers to brand-name drugs on a formulary that are not in the preferred tier, usually resulting in higher copayments or coinsurance compared to preferred brand-name drugs.

Refers to specialty drugs that are high-cost, complex medications placed in a non-preferred tier on insurance formularies, leading to higher patient cost-sharing and often requiring special handling and prior authorization.
Brand-name drugs on an insurance formulary that are favored due to negotiated discounts or rebates, resulting in lower copayments or coinsurance compared to non-preferred brand drugs.

Refers to specialty brand-name drugs that are preferred on an insurance formulary for their cost-effectiveness compared to alternatives, resulting in lower patient costs than non-preferred specialty drugs while still addressing serious or rare conditions requiring special handling.
Only available for select plans. Refer to member plan documents for coverage.
Only available for select plans. Refer to member plan documents for coverage.
Generic drugs that are favored on an insurance formulary due to their lower cost and availability, resulting in the lowest copayments for patients compared to brand-name or non-preferred drugs.
Minimum and maximum age requirements set by an insurance policy or plan that determine when an individual can apply for coverage or renew a policy, often used to manage risk and eligibility.

Insurance coverage for a drug or treatment is determined based on the specific medical condition or indication for which the drug is prescribed, often requiring that the drug be used only for FDA-approved or medically supported indications to qualify for coverage.

EXPANSION: Drug Coverage for Student Health members.
Explanation: Drug Coverage for Student Health members means that prescription drug coverage is provided as part of the student health insurance plan, helping to cover the costs of necessary medications prescribed during their studies, often including both acute and ongoing treatments.

EXPANSION: Drug tier when CE does not apply
Explanation: Drug tier when CE does not apply means the drug is assigned to a specific coverage tier in the formulary where clinical effectiveness (CE) criteria or certain utilization management rules do not influence the tier placement or coverage decision, often resulting in standard tier-based cost sharing without exceptions based on clinical criteria.

EXPANSION: (Quantiy Limit) QL Restriction based on Age
Explanation: Quantity Limit Restriction Based on Age means that the insurance plan imposes limits on the amount or quantity of a drug that can be dispensed, with these limits varying depending on the patient’s age to ensure safe and appropriate usage.
Only available for select plans. Refer to member plan documents for coverage.

EXPANSION: Safer and/or more effective treatments are available
Explanation: STX means that safer and/or more effective treatments are available for a condition, and insurance or healthcare may prefer or require these treatments over others due to better outcomes, lower risks, or improved safety profiles.

Explanation: Quantity Limit Restriction Based on Age means that the insurance plan imposes limits on the amount or quantity of a drug that can be dispensed, with these limits varying depending on the patient’s age to ensure safe and appropriate usage.
Available to some members at no cost with a prescription from your provider when obtained at an in-network pharmacy. Certain limitations may apply.
Non-preferred generic and non-preferred brand Drug name drugs

Refers to specialty drugs that are high-cost, complex medications placed in a non-preferred tier on insurance formularies, leading to higher patient cost-sharing and often requiring special handling and prior authorization.
Brand-name drugs on an insurance formulary that are favored due to negotiated discounts or rebates, resulting in lower copayments or coinsurance compared to non-preferred brand drugs.
Generic drugs that are favored on an insurance formulary due to their lower cost and availability, resulting in the lowest copayments for patients compared to brand-name or non-preferred drugs.

Refers to specialty brand-name drugs that are preferred on an insurance formulary for their cost-effectiveness compared to alternatives, resulting in lower patient costs than non-preferred specialty drugs while still addressing serious or rare conditions requiring special handling.
Minimum and maximum age requirements set by an insurance policy or plan that determine when an individual can apply for coverage or renew a policy, often used to manage risk and eligibility.
ST (immediate release (IR) opioid before extended release (ER) opioid) does not apply to Individual plans.

Insurance coverage for a drug or treatment is determined based on the specific medical condition or indication for which the drug is prescribed, often requiring that the drug be used only for FDA-approved or medically supported indications to qualify for coverage.

when a generic version of a drug is available, the patient pays the lowest copayment amount applicable to the generic drug tier, ensuring the lowest out-of-pocket cost compared to brand-name alternatives.

EXPANSION: Drug tier when CE does not apply
Explanation: Drug tier when CE does not apply means the drug is assigned to a specific coverage tier in the formulary where clinical effectiveness (CE) criteria or certain utilization management rules do not influence the tier placement or coverage decision, often resulting in standard tier-based cost sharing without exceptions based on clinical criteria.
Only available for select plans. Refer to member plan documents for coverage.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

EXPANSION: (Quantiy Limit) QL Restriction based on Age
Explanation: Quantity Limit Restriction Based on Age means that the insurance plan imposes limits on the amount or quantity of a drug that can be dispensed, with these limits varying depending on the patient’s age to ensure safe and appropriate usage.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.
